Summary: The proposal introduces adaptive model-based priors (AMPs) to improve the sample efficiency of reinforcement learning (RL) by combining hierarchical Bayesian dynamics models, uncertainty-aware policy optimization, and meta-learning priors across tasks. The experiment plan includes validation on synthetic benchmarks, continuous control tasks, cross-task generalization, high-dimensional observations, and a real-world feasibility study.
Strengths: Clear problem statement highlighting the sample inefficiency of current RL methods.
Compelling hypothesis suggesting adaptive priors can address rigidity in MBRL.
Ambitious proposed method combining hierarchical Bayesian models, uncertainty-aware policy optimization, and meta-learning.
Detailed experiment plan covering a range of scenarios from synthetic to real-world tasks.
Weaknesses: Lacks technical depth in explaining the implementation of hierarchical Bayesian dynamics models.
Uncertainty-aware policy optimization derivation is not thoroughly discussed.
Scalability to high-dimensional observations is not thoroughly addressed.
Real-world feasibility study is somewhat vague.
Questions: How will the hierarchical Bayesian dynamics models be implemented in practice?
Can you provide more details on the derivation of the uncertainty-aware policy optimization?
What are the potential challenges in scaling the method to high-dimensional observations?
How will the real-world feasibility study be conducted, and what metrics will be used to quantify success?
Limitations: Potential challenges in implementing hierarchical Bayesian dynamics models.
Scalability to high-dimensional observations may be limited.
Real-world deployment may face unforeseen technical hurdles.
